item.title: China coronavirus: Wuhan and Huanggang on lockdown
item.description: There are more than 500 confirmed cases of the virus, which has also spread abroad.

item.title: East Kent hospitals: Baby death parents’ heartbreak over errors
item.description: At least seven babies have died since 2016 at one of the largest hospital groups in England, the BBC finds.

item.title: John Bercow: Formal complaint lodged against former Commons Speaker
item.description: Accusations against the ex-Speaker by one of his most senior advisers are thought to centre around bullying.

item.title: Myanmar Rohingya: World court orders prevention of genocide
item.description: The decision comes despite Myanmar de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi's defence arguments.

item.title: Australia fires: US crew dead in firefighting plane crash
item.description: Three people are dead after a large air tanker went down fighting bushfires in New South Wales.

item.title: Auschwitz: Prince Charles to warn world leaders over 'hatred'
item.description: On a visit to Israel, he will tell US, Russian and French leaders of the lessons of the Holocaust.

item.title: Jessica Simpson reveals childhood sexual abuse
item.description: The singer reveals in her new book how a childhood incident led to a reliance on drugs and alcohol.

item.title: Isabel dos Santos: Africa's richest woman accused of fraud
item.description: Africa's richest woman is provisionally charged with embezzlement by her country's prosecutors.

item.title: Two weeks of leave for UK parents who lose a child
item.description: The law, which will come into force in April, will be the most generous in the world, ministers say.

item.title: Victoria Derbyshire says 'we don't give up' after her TV show is cut
item.description: Victoria Derbyshire addresses the news that her TV show is coming off air, saying "we're still here".

item.title: Juice WRLD: Rapper died from accidental overdose of painkillers, coroner rules
item.description: A medical examiner has ruled that the rapper died as a result of oxycodone and codeine toxicity,

item.title: Harry and Meghan: How much privacy can they expect in Canada?
item.description: The couple complained about media intrusion within hours of relocating to Vancouver, Canada.

item.title: 'I helped convict the bishop who abused me'
item.description: Sexual abuse survivors tell of their grooming at the hands of Bishop Peter Ball.

item.title: Jean-Paul Gaultier: Stars turn out for designer's final show
item.description: French fashion designer Jean-Paul Gaultier ends a 50-year career with his last couture runway show.

item.title: Running and male suicide: ‘Running almost pushed me over the edge’
item.description: Mark used running to cope with his friend’s suicide. But it grew to take over his identity.

item.title: The Papers: Fears over deadly virus and 'sour' UK-US relations
item.description: Thursday's newspapers feature a range of stories, including the latest on the Chinese coronavirus.

item.title: Ivory Coast is using plastic waste to build schools
item.description: The West African country has partnered with UNICEF to transform landfill waste into bricks for schools.

item.title: Three generations join Delhi women's citizenship sit-in
item.description: Thousands of women are camping out in a Delhi suburb in protest over a law they see as anti-Muslim.

item.title: Lions and tigers escape circus for vast new home
item.description: Seventeen big cats rescued from Guatemalan circuses have moved to a South African wildlife sanctuary.

item.title: Does a milk advert show Harry and Meghan's future?
item.description: As the Queen's grandson sells Jersey milk in China, critics call for clarity over royal endorsements.

item.title: Terry Jones: Life in pictures
item.description: Pictures from the life of The Monty Python star Terry Jones, who has died at the age of 77.

item.title: Davos 2020: Prince Charles meets Greta Thunberg
item.description: The heir to the throne calls for a "paradigm shift" in the way the world deals with climate change.

item.title: Stranded dolphins rescued from mud in Thames Estuary
item.description: It took rescuers two hours to free the pair after the mammals became stuck in muddy waters.

item.title: Can wearing masks stop the spread of viruses?
item.description: Surgical masks have been used to prevent illness in China for decades.

item.title: Auschwitz: How death camp became centre of Nazi Holocaust
item.description: It is 75 years since Soviet Union troops liberated Auschwitz - now marked as Holocaust Memorial Day.

item.title: Why is 'pettifogging' suddenly in the news?
item.description: The word has all but disappeared from modern usage - so what does it mean and why is it relevant?

item.title: Overdrafts: Why you shouldn't ignore that message from your bank about fees
item.description: Overdrafts are undergoing their biggest change in a generation and it could double your costs.

item.title: Coronavirus: How do you quarantine a city - and does it work?
item.description: People in Wuhan are being stopped from leaving - but it may not prevent the virus from spreading.

item.title: Problem gambling: Why do some people become addicted?
item.description: Over half of Britons gambled in the past year, so why does it become a problem for some?

item.title: 'I have to live on $1,175 a year'
item.description: Brazil's army of fruit workers speak of struggling with low pay and dangerous working conditions.

item.title: Tyson Fury: How Manchester fighter has built his following - and plans to break America
item.description: Few might have predicted the marketing success of Tyson Fury. Imagination, charisma, talent - and honesty. This is how he did it.

item.title: My Money: 'I had to get tickets, it was a huge sum, $519!'
item.description: As part of a BBC blog series, Sunneva María Svövudóttir from Iceland shares what she spent this week.

item.title: Beyond Veganuary: Is going plant-based a smart way to lose weight?
item.description: People with eating disorders may use veganism as a "socially acceptable" restrictive diet, a charity warns.

item.title: The writers breathing life into black British history
item.description: Several little-known but remarkable stories of the 18th and 19th Centuries are being told on stage.

item.title: What happens when we're too old to be 'useful'?
item.description: Can we afford to pay pensions, given the huge demographic challenge of our ageing population?

item.title: What is universal credit - and what's the problem?
item.description: Universal credit was designed to simplify the welfare system but its introduction has proved controversial.

item.title: China coronavirus: Your questions answered
item.description: Are airports screening arrivals? Can the virus affect anyone who has travelled to China recently?

item.title: Rough sex murder defence: Why campaigners want it banned
item.description: Campaigners say men are increasingly using the defence to try to get away with murdering women.

item.title: Sirius: 'You feel sorry for people who've invested a lot'
item.description: Mining giant Anglo American will buy Sirius, but for only a quarter of what it was worth months ago.

item.title: 'Toxic, embarrassing, worst squad in 30 years' - pundits and fans on Man Utd defeat
item.description: Manchester United's latest defeat has seen the atmosphere turn "toxic" at Old Trafford, says former midfielder Darren Fletcher.

item.title: British singles interest ends at Australian Open as Dart & Watson beaten
item.description: Harriet Dart and Heather Watson are both beaten by seeds as British interest in the Australian Open singles ends on day four.

item.title: Manchester United 'not good enough' in Burnley defeat - Solskjaer
item.description: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer says Manchester United were "not good enough" in their 2-0 defeat against Burnley at Old Trafford.

item.title: 'I design shoes for Cristiano Ronaldo, the Beckhams and Justin Timberlake'
item.description: "Kickasso" makes a special shoe for Juventus' Cristiano Ronaldo and explains how he designed footwear for David Beckham's son, Ashley Cole, Justin Timberlake and Odell Beckham Jr.

item.title: How a boy from Vietnam became a slave on a UK cannabis farm
item.description: Ba was a street child in Ho Chi Minh city. He ended up growing cannabis as a slave in the UK - until he escaped.
